image:image.image:title: Top_Hat!_Brachypterygius_mordax_BRSMG_Ce_16696_exhibit
image:image.image:caption: The ichthyosaur Brachypterygius extremus from the Upper Jurassic of Kimmeridge Bay on the Jurassic Coast of the UK. A few accessories have been added.

image:image.image:title: 11146398_10153744852488448_5694720390716190845_o
image:image.image:caption: The conference photograph taken by David Marshall.

image:image.image:title: 200 years of ichthyosaurology
image:image.image:caption: The skull illustrated in Home (1814) I can't read the caption to tell who the illustrator is. Text added by me.

image:image.image:title: 2013-06-15 publications
image:image.image:caption: ￼Ichthyosaur publications and authors from their first description (Home 1814) through to the present day (halfway through 2013). I should point out that these are only the ones that I know of and are certainly not all.

image:image.image:title: uJichth PCO1-2 new
image:image.image:caption: Intraspecific variation of humeri in Upper Jurassic ichthyosaurs, including Ophthalmosaurus icenicus (red), Brachypterygius extremus (blue), Nannopterygius enthekiodon (green) and LEICT G1.2001.016 (pink).

image:image.image:title: Maxwell2012_Stenopterygius_morphospace
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Morphospace plot of Stenopterygius from the Posidonienschiefer. This shows the distributions of three species: S. quadriscissus, S. triscissus and S. uniter. Component 1 is related to size and growth. The starred specimens are embryos (to the left) and their mothers (to the right). Circled points are type specimens. (From Maxwell 2012a.)

image:image.image:title: Temnodontosaurus_CFD
image:image.image:caption: Figure 14. Preliminary fluid dynamics testing. The silhouette is of Temnodontosaurus from Motani (2005).

image:image.image:title: Rothschildatal2012_decompression_Leptonectes
image:image.image:caption: Figure 8. The effects of ‘the bends’ can be seen in the bones of this Leptonectes tenuirostris. The bone cells are killed, and the stricture weakened, which causes failure when the bone is loaded. the shaft of the arrow is 40 mm. (From Rothschild, Xiaoting and Martin 2012.)

image:image.image:title: Reisdorfetal2012_Stenopterygius_'exploded'
image:image.image:caption: Figure 9. The scattered remains of a Stenopterygius from the Posidonienschiefer. Specimens with the bones spread like this are not uncommon. The diffuse substrate and even low-velocity currents are the likely cause of this preservation. (From Reisdorf et al. 2012.)

image:image.image:title: Reidorfetal2012_exploding_whale_stills
image:image.image:caption: Figure 10. Stills from the above video showing the effect of sticking a pointed stick into a bloated whale. (From Reisdorf et al. 2012.)

image:image.image:title: Organetal2012_Stenopterygius_quadriscissus_birth
image:image.image:caption: Figure 7. A famous Stenopterygius specimen. This is usually interpreted as an adult with a juvenile in the process of being birthed: ichthyosaurs gave birth to live young, as with modern mammals. It is this, among other things, that likely allowed them to become so highly adapted to their marine lifestye. (From Organ et al. 2009.)

image:image.image:title: NHM_Ophthalmosaurus
image:image.image:caption: Figure 11. Ophthalmosaurus icenicus in the main hall at the Natural History Museum, London. This specimen is about 5 m long.

image:image.image:title: NHM_Nannopterygius
image:image.image:caption: Figure 13. Nannopterygius enthekiodon, the best photo I could in the Natural History Museum, London. The specimen is about 3 m long.

image:image.image:title: Maxwelletal2012_Stenopterygius_aaleniensis
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Stenopterygius aaleniensis from the Aalenian of southwestern Germany. this shows the unusual preservation where the body is largely seen side-on, but the head and shoulders are face-on. A is the type specimen and B an interpretative drawing. (From Maxwell, Fernández and Schoch 2012.)

image:image.image:title: Martinetal2012_Temnodontosaurus_azerguensis
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. Temnodontosaurus azerguensis from the Toarcian of France. This large ichthyosaur is odd as there are no teeth associated with it, other Temnodontosaurus are well known for having big teeth. (From Martin et al. 2012.)

image:image.image:title: Young Stenopterygius
image:image.image:caption: Stenopterygius quadriscissus from the Posidonienschiefer of Southwest Germany. This is a young individual, but exquisitely preserved: all elements in articulation and a preservation of the body outline. Photograph by Heinrich Mallison.

image:image.image:title: Thalattoarchon saurophagis
image:image.image:caption: Thalattoarchon saurophagis looking big mean and ichthyosaurian. Here it’s chasing a smaller mixosaur (e.g. Phalarodon) which has been found nearby. Artwork by Raul Martin.

image:image.image:title: Druckenmilleretal_2012_Cryopterygius
image:image.image:caption: Cryopterygius kristiansenae near-complete skeleton showing the left side. the skull and forepaddle are clearly preserved in profile. From Druckenmiller et al. 2012.

image:image.image:title: Druckenmilleretal_2012_Palvennia
image:image.image:caption: Palvennia hoybergeti, skull in dorsal(ish) view. The skull has been crushed so that the side can also be seen. From Druckenmiller et al. 2012.

image:image.image:title: Druckenmilleretal_2012_geology
image:image.image:caption: The geology on the southern bank of the Isfjord, Svalbard (inset), showing the local geology and location of the finds. From Druckenmiller et al. 2012.

image:image.image:title: Leicester NWM interior
image:image.image:caption: The hidden bowels of the New Walk Museum, Leicester, showing the collections on shelves, trolleys and in drawers in cupboards in stacks on rollers.

image:image.image:title: cropped-brachypterygius-mordax-brsmg-ce-16696-exhibit1.jpg
image:image.image:caption: Brachypterygius mordax composite photo of specimen Ce 16696 from Bristol Museum and Art Gallery.

image:image.image:title: WBP banner
image:image.image:caption: The Weymouth Bay Pliosaur in dorsal (left) and right lateral (right) views.

image:image.image:title: Brachypterygius BRSMG Ce 16696 skull piece mixed 100dpi
image:image.image:caption: Brachypterygius sp., skull piece and interpretation, from the Bristol Museum (undescribed & unfigured specimen Ce 16696). This is the treat I spoke of in a previous post. [Thanks to Paul for commenting on the labelling — what I had labelled as the angulars are more likely splenials.]

image:image.image:title: Brachypterygius BRSMG Ce 16696 skull piece oriented mix
image:image.image:caption: Brachypterygius sp., skull piece and interpretation, from the Bristol Museum (specimen Ce 16696).

image:image.image:title: Brachypterygius extremus forepaddle2
image:image.image:caption: Brachypterygius extremus forepaddle, specimen in the Natural History Museum (specimen R3177).

image:image.image:title: SMCJ68516(McGowanMotani2003)
image:image.image:caption: Brachypterygius mordax, a large, complete but crushed skull in the Sedgwick Museum, Cambridge (SMC J68516) (from McGowan and Motani 2003).

image:image.image:title: Brachypterygius mordax BRSMG Ce 16696 exhibit
image:image.image:caption: A Kimmeridgian ichthyosaur (Grendelius mordax) from Somerset, UK. Housed in Bristol Museum (Ce 16696). This is a composite photograph so not perfectly joined.

image:image.image:title: NHMUK Ichthyosaurus leptospondylus
image:image.image:caption: Ichthyosaurs leptopterygius from the Solnhofen Limestone of southern Germany. Significantly crushed, in dorsal view.

image:image.image:title: NHMUK 46497a
image:image.image:caption: Isolated hindpaddle of Nannopterygius enthekiodon, from the Kimmeridgian, in most views as suggested on SV-POW. There has been some slight dorsoventral crushing, hence the significant difference in size of the proximal femoral processes. Abbreviations: car: carpal, dp: dorsal process, fem: femur, fib: fibula, int: intermedium, tbl tibiale, tib: tibia, vp: ventral process.

image:image.image:title: NHMUK 'Nanno' vertebral series
image:image.image:caption: Unidentified ‘ichthyosaur’ vertebrae in the collections of the Natural History Museum, London. Still in their plaster wrapping, centra with articulated neural spines.

image:image.image:title: Besanosaurus map
image:image.image:caption: Besanosaurus leptorhynchus from the Besano Formation (Grenzbitumenzone) near Besano, northern Italy. From Dal Sasso and Pinna (1996).

image:image.image:title: Biostratigraphy
image:image.image:caption: Example of correlation over sections using fossils. Each stratum with a certain fossil was deposited at a certain time. The different thicknesses can be caused by different sedimentation rates or the spread of the species itself. Where there is no occurrence, indicates that so sediment was deposited, the species could not colonise that environment or there has been erosion causing an unconformity.

image:image.image:title: Never too old
image:image.image:caption: Georgia MacLean-Henry and myself (left) dino-ing it up at Dorset County Museum

image:image.image:title: Sander 2000 Stenopterygius
image:image.image:caption: Stenopterygius from the Lower Jurassic of southern Germany. This is very commonly found in quarries and is represented by thousands of specimens. The preservation can be so good that the original skin outline and even some of its structure may be seen. This typical thunniform ichthyosaur shows the fusiform shape, larger forelimb and crescent tail typical of Jurassic and Cretaceous species. From Sander (2000).

image:image.image:title: Sander 2000 Ophthalmosaurus
image:image.image:caption: The Late Jurassic ichthyosaur Ophthalmosaurus shows much similarity to Stenopterygius. The extremely large eye is characteristic of the genus, although it also features reduced pectoral and pelvic girdles and is more barrel-chested. From Sander (2000).

image:image.image:title: Sander 2000 Mixosaurus
image:image.image:caption: The Triassic ichthyosaur Mixosaurus cornalianus from the southern Alps. The Triassic ichthyosaurs had a less defined tail fin and more similarly sized paddles. Mixosaurus cornalianus had very long neural spines (above the backbone), a feature characteristic to the species. From Sander (2000).

image:image.image:title: Hunterian Museum Stenopterygius An ichthyosaur with soft tissue preservation
image:image.image:caption: A very well preserved ichthyosaur (Stenopterygius) from the Posidonienschiefer of southern Germany showing exceptional preservation and skin outline. Copyright © University of Glasgow/Hunterian Museum (taken with permission from http://www.hmag.gla.ac.uk/Neil/reprods/).

image:image.image:title: Ophthalmosaurus McG Mot 2003 Sk
image:image.image:caption: Fig. 3 Skull of Ophthalmosaurus icenicus showing the very large orbit, where the eye sits. The ring of bones (sclerotic ring) would have kept the shape of the eye and assisted in focussing underwater. Modified from McGowan and Motani (2003).

image:image.image:title: Ophthalmosaurus icenicus reconstruction
image:image.image:caption: Fig. 1 Reconstruction of Ophthalmosaurus icenicus (modified from Kirton 1983).

image:image.image:title: Ophthalmosaurus BMNH R3702 RfpD
image:image.image:caption: Fig. 2 Right forepaddle of Ophthalmosaurus icenicus from the Oxford Clay of Peterborough (BMNH R3702) in dorsal view. Note the three facets on the distal end of the humerus and the large number of digits (arab numerals) and phalanges (roman numerals). The anterior- and posteriormost digits are accessory digits (modified from Kirton 1983).

image:image.image:title: Nannopterygius McG Mot 2003 body
image:image.image:caption: Fig. 5 Nannopterygius enthekiodon from the Kimmeridge Clay of Dorset (specimen BMNH 46497). Note the very small paddles compared to the rest of the body. Modified from McGowan and Motani (2003).

image:image.image:title: Brachypterygius BMNH R3177 RfpD
image:image.image:caption: Fig. 4 Brachypterygius extremes forepaddle showing the three equally sized distal humeral facets articulating with the radius, intermedium and ulna. Specimen BMNH R3177 (modified from Kirton 1983).

image:image.image:title: Ichthyosaur cladograms 1999–2000
image:image.image:caption: Fig. 2 Three phylogenies of ichthyosaurs proposed in 1999–2000. A from Motani (1999), B modified from Sander (2000) and C from Maisch and Matzke (2000). Names on the right indicate the taxa involved in the analysis. Names of clades are given in A and B. Clade number are given at branchings in C. Temno. refers to Temnodontosaurus, a Lower Jurassic ichthyosaur.

image:image.image:title: Phylo matrix
image:image.image:caption: Table 1 Data matrix for five taxa (A–E) with 10 characters (1–10). All characters except five are two-state — character five is three-state. Uncertainty is indicated by ‘?’ and missing data by ‘-’.

image:image.image:title: cladogram example
image:image.image:caption: Fig. 1 Example cladogram created from the matrix in table 1 using PHYLIP 3.69 (Felsenstein 2009). This analysis shows that E and B are closely related and most derived. Their clade, A and C could not be resolved fully, resulting in a polytomy. D is the least derived. D is the outgroup to all others. Also, A, C and D is the outgroup to B and E.

image:image.image:title: Rayfield 2005 CAT
image:image.image:caption: Fig. 2 Finite Element analysis of three theropod dinosaurs, Coelophysis, Allosaurus, and Tyrannosaurus. Top diagrams show the fossils. Middle diagrams are the surface mesh, arrows show fulcra. Lower diagrams show stresses under FEA analysis, warmer colours indicate higher forces, arrows show force transferral. Modified from Rayfield (2005).

image:image.image:title: Thorne et al disparity
image:image.image:caption: Fig. 1 Ichthyosaur disparity decreased over the TJB more than diversity. From Thorne et al. 2011.

image:image.image:title: Earth Chronostratigraphic Chart
image:image.image:caption: The history of the Earth with chronostratigraphic divisions based upon Ogg et al. (2008). Key events are also present and will be added to over time. (Click to view larger version.)
